Chapter 9, section 2: Distinguishing the Differences, part 9. The characteristics of the six causes have already been discussed. The world definitely establishes the name of cause in relation to the effect.
What are called the effects corresponding to the causes?
Verse:ğŸ”½Effects are conditioned, unconditioned, and unattached,
Unconditioned has no cause or effect.
Discussion:
There are five kinds of effects, which will be discussed in detail later. For now, they are briefly indicated as conditioned and unattached.
As the Abhidharma says:
What are the dharmas of effect?
It means all conditioned dharmas and the cessation obtained through discrimination.
Isn't it that because cessation obtained through discrimination is accepted as an effect, it must have a cause?
It is not that without a cause it can be said to be an effect, because it has never been seen.
I also accept the path as the cause for its realization, because the sÅ«tras say it is the effect of Å›ramaá¹‡as.
From which of these six causes is it obtained?
I say that this result is not from the six causes, because the six causes previously mentioned are what is relied upon for production.
If that is so, then you should admit that this realization is a cause, apart from the previous six causes, as a seventh.
The position accepted by our school is as you have stated. Isn't there such a recitation in your school that nirvana is a result but has no cause?
Although there is this recitation, there is no error in the meaning.
That is to say, in the world, when one has accomplished what one desires through exertion, it is commonly called a result.
Death is the greatest calamity for a person, so non-death is what a person most desires.
This most desired [state] is attained through the exertion of the path, so it is called a result.

As for saying it has no cause, the path is not one of the six causes in relation to the unconditioned cessation that is attained.ğŸ”½Cessation is not a result produced by the path, but a result realized by the path;
the path is not a productive cause in relation to cessation, but a realizing cause.
Therefore, the path and cessation are mutually corresponding, and cause and effect and right and wrong cannot be definitively stated.
If the path is the cause of realizing cessation, then it should only be said to be the fruit of the path.
Who says that the fruit of the path is definitely not the attainment of cessation?
Because the path is the homogeneous cause of the attainment of cessation, or it is also said to be the coexistent cause.

However, this is not the holy fruit that is truly sought, because the noble ones, with the cessation they have attained included in their minds, practice the holy path. Therefore, the superior fruit of the path is only the cessation that is attained, not the attainment of cessation, because the noble ones do not practice the holy path in order to seek conditioned dharmas.
Therefore, the BhagavÄn said in the sÅ«tras that the fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a are only the severing of bonds, not the realization of the path.
The path of cultivation is not without use, because when the first moment of the path is attained, what should be done has already been accomplished.
If you admit that cessation through discrimination is the efficient cause, you must admit that nirvÄá¹‡a has a dominant fruit.
It is not that extinction obtained through contemplation is like sound, etc., in having a productive function when the eye, etc., are produced.
That is, when conditioned dharmas are in the state of being produced, neither conditioned nor unconditioned dharmas obstruct them, and therefore all dharmas can be causes.
However, only past and present dharmas among conditioned dharmas have the function of taking and giving, and are said to have results.
Future dharmas and unconditioned dharmas do not have this function, and therefore they do not have results.
Therefore a scripture says:
All causes and conditions that produce consciousness are impermanent.
Although unconditioned dharmas are causes and conditions, they cannot produce, and therefore the Buddha did not say so.
As discussed previously in the consideration of the efficient cause, the efficient cause is briefly of two kinds:
one has the power to produce, and the other merely does not obstruct. Therefore unconditioned dharmas are causes that do not obstruct, but because they cannot produce, they do not have results.
Isnâ€™t it the case that a scripture says:
The mental consciousness is produced with mind and dharmas as conditions?
Why is unconditioned dharmas included in dharmas but unable to produce?
Based on the majority being able to produce, this is said in an implicit manner. How can it be prevented that a small part is unable to produce?
Or, unconditioned dharmas are also able to produce consciousness. However, consciousness is not a result, as explained before, because it is not able to produce.
If it is able to produce subsequent consciousness, it would be impermanent.

Due to this principle, conditioned dharmas establish cause and effect, but unconditioned dharmas do not. Therefore, cessation through discernment is cause without result, and is result without cause. The principle is extremely established.

Here, there are many types that slander nirvÄá¹‡a. The causes for their slander are not uniform. I will now refute the master of the treatise's causes for slander and also refute other teachers, establishing cessation through discernment. Due to this, I will also discuss the other two unconditioned dharmas.
Here, the master of the treatise cites the SautrÄntika theory that all unconditioned dharmas do not really exist, because they do not exist separately as real substances like form, feeling, etc.
However, the scriptures say that only the absence of contact is called space. When in the dark there is no contact, one says:

This is space.ğŸ”½When the seeds of the already arisen latent afflictions are destroyed, due to the power of discernment the remaining [afflictions] do not arise again, and this is called cessation through discernment.

Apart from the power of discernment, due to the lack of conditions the remaining [afflictions] do not arise again, and this is called cessation not through discernment, like the remaining aggregates of one who dies prematurely.
This is all unreasonable, because there is no evidence.
First, regarding what they say, that only the absence of contact is called space, and that space is the absence of contact, we also believe and accept this, because space is without contact.
As for the statement that only the absence of contact is called space, and that it does not have a separate substance, what evidence is there for this?
It has already been proven that in the dark there is no contact, and then one says:
This is space.
Isn't this evidence able to prove that it does not exist? It is not only by using this statement as evidence that one can prove that space definitely does not exist.
They only say that this is space, which is not in contact with anything.
How do we know that they only say space is the absence of contact?
As the world says:
This pleasure is not suffering.
How can it be that only the absence of suffering is called pleasure?
If it is not so, then the two feelings of suffering and pleasure have harm and benefit, because their functions are different.

This space has little function, and it cannot be obtained like pleasure, so the analogy is not the same. This means that the previous reason should be useless, because now it is only used to prove that space definitely does not exist because it has no function that can be obtained.

Moreover, it cannot be definitely used as a reason that space is said to be the absence of contact to prove that the substance of space is only the absence of contact. This means that the author of the treatise has no reason here that can prove that space definitely does not exist.
Moreover, a scripture says:
Unconditioned space exists because it has a function, and it is not like pleasure.
As the World-Honored One said:
Wind relies on space, without action there is reliance, not with mental grasping.
Moreover, light color is the characteristic of space.
Therefore, we know that the substance of space truly exists.
As a sutra says:
However, it relies on light for space to be revealed.
This definitely shows the characteristic of space, namely light. Therefore, the sutra again says this:
The Buddha previously said that wind relies on space, and later said that space has no support. Do not let those Brahmins give rise to such doubts:
How can we know that space exists?
Yet the World-Honored One says that wind relies on space. To dispel their doubts, he again says this.
If space does not exist, what need is there for light?
Light has color, is visible, and has resistance.
If there were no space, what could contain it?
Therefore, the World-Honored One says that it relies on light for space to be revealed. This reveals that light color can serve as the characteristic of the true existence of space.
However, that elder did not understand the meaning expressed in this sÅ«tra and falsely asked this question:
If it is illuminated by light, and space is manifested, then space should be categorized as a form dharma.
How did this question come about?
Moreover, the essence of space should actually not be nonexistent, because in the sÅ«tras it is said to be like the mind.
As a sÅ«tra says:
Space is without form, invisible, and unimpeded. What does it depend on?
It cannot be said that there is such a distinction in the self or in the horns of a rabbit.
Here, he explained this statement in response to the question.
As a sÅ«tra says:
Well-tamed is my self.
The self is the basis. If this statement is made in response to a question, it should not be said like this, but should simply say:
Brahmin!
Space has no substance. What does it depend on?
Also, it should not be said that it is manifested by light and space, but that it can be known in the past and the agent can be obtained. It should be said to be a true answer to a question;
if it is said to exist where it does not exist, this statement becomes meaningless speech.
Also, the cited analogy is incapable of proving anything, because it speaks of the self and the basis of the self in relation to the mind.
This has already been extensively examined in the internal [doctrines].
If the words formless, etc. have no real meaning, what is this analogy used to prove?
Also, what they say:
If the substance of space exists in the slightest, because space is permanent, then obstructive form should never arise.
Or it should be allowed that this is included in the conditioned, like the son of Vaccha.
They speak thus without careful consideration.

Because the space they grasp cannot contain other obstructing forms, and because the substance of space is not obstructed by other forms, when other forms arise, space does not make way for them, and the error of space being impermanent results.
However, because space is by nature accommodating and not form, it does not need to make way for other forms.

Because the substance of the realm of empty space is an obstructing form, when other forms arise, it must make way for them. That is, the realm of empty space is a subtle form that, although it does not obstruct other forms, is itself obstructed by other forms and is therefore impermanent and conditioned.
However, the characteristics of space do not obstruct other forms nor are they obstructed by other forms. How can the arising of form be impermanent and conditioned?
Space and form can coexist without contradiction, and therefore space does not arise or perish in the various states of form.
However, there is obstruction in walls, etc., because forms that obstruct exist there and obstruct other forms, not because the unconditioned does not exist there.
The color of the realm of space is subtle, light, and fine, and cannot obstruct the other colors. When the other coarse and heavy colors are pushed and blocked, it immediately gives way.
All opposed colors should be like this. If one occupies a place, there is definitely no second.
Space is unobstructed and different from the realm of space. How can it be compared to them and be impermanent?
Moreover, what they say:
If the substance of space really exists, it should be conditioned, because it is no different from the realm of space.
They have empty words but no real principle, because the World-Honored One himself says there is a difference.
As a sutra says:
Space is without form, invisible, and without obstruction.
It also says:
When the realm of space is separated from attachment to form, it is abandoned together with the four [other aggregates].

If the realm of space is no different from space, and space is without form, invisible, and without obstruction, the realm of space should be the same. It should be said that when one is separated from attachment to the formless realm, it is abandoned.
Also, a scripture says that the realm of empty space constitutes a provisional person, and it says that empty space is manifested by light.
If the realm of empty space is identical to empty space, and if light is the realm of empty space, how can a scripture say that light is manifested by light?
Therefore we know that there is a difference.
Also, a scripture says:
Among all dharmas, whether conditioned or unconditioned, freedom from impurity is the most important.
In this scripture, dharmas are of two kinds. Unconditioned dharmas cannot be said to be nonexistent, because they cannot be said to be the nature of dharmas that lack substance.

The term unconditioned indicates that there are many kinds of unconditioned dharmas, namely, empty space and cessation resulting from discrimination. Only these can be said to be many, because apart from these there are no other unconditioned dharmas.
Therefore the realm of empty space is not identical to empty space.
The Sthavira does not think about this and says that the two are not different.
Other masters say:
There is no separate empty space, because there is no awareness of empty space in the absence of obstructive form.
Their explanation is unreasonable, because this very reason proves that space has a separate substance.
Space, which is different from the obstruction of form, exists separately and can be the object of perception, because it produces the cognition of emptiness.
If there were no object, cognition would not arise.
Therefore, their explanation is mere empty words.
Moreover, it can be said that there is no unobstructed form in space, because the cognition of form arises.
However, this does not prove that form does not exist, so it cannot prove that space does not exist.

If it is said that the substance of form can be known, space should also be so, because it can be inferred to exist. It is said that although the eyes, etc. are not directly perceived, they exist because they have a function.
In the same way, space also has a function, so it can be inferred to exist.
The function is as explained above. Therefore, space has a separate real substance.
Moreover, they say:

When the seeds that give rise to the already arisen latent afflictions are extinguished, the remaining [afflictions] do not arise again due to the power of discernment. This is called cessation through discernment.

Thus the theory of cessation through discrimination is not established, because there is no difference between the nonarising of dharmas due to the absence of a condition and the nonarising of dharmas due to the power of discrimination.
We ask, what is the difference between the two kinds of nonarising?
Also, there is nonarising apart from the holy path. Why is it useless to cultivate the path?

It is not useless, because the power of the path of cultivation can destroy the future passions and the seeds of dharmas that are not yet born, and because, by the destruction of the seeds, it causes future passions and suffering not to be born.
If you do not admit this, by the power of what are they not born?
The seeds held to exist by the DÄrá¹£á¹­Äntikas have already been uprooted in the discussion of the question of whether or not seeds exist. What is left to discuss?

Even if we admit that seeds are not nonexistent, if these propensities, etc., are not born again later because of the absence of a condition, or if they are not born again because the power of discrimination destroys the seeds, what is the difference between the two?
Also, dharmas that are not produced are like the past and definitely will not be produced again. What need is there to eliminate them?

Even though the seeds have not yet been eliminated, the dharmas that they produce will definitely not be produced again, just as if they had already been eliminated. Therefore, the path of elimination that is cultivated with effort would be useless.

Isnâ€™t it the case that your school also diligently applies expedient means to the dharmas that have already attained cessation not due to deliberation, and eliminates them by cultivating the path of elimination?

Our school is possible in this way, because it is said that one universally eliminates the delusions and suffering of the three time periods, and realizes nirvÄá¹‡a. Dharmas that are not produced are like the past and obtain the ability to obstruct nirvÄá¹‡a, and therefore must be eliminated again.

Your school is not like this, because it only says that the latent tendencies and the non-production of suffering are nirvÄá¹‡a. Therefore, even though the seeds have not yet been eliminated, there is non-production that is just like having already been eliminated and definitely not produced again. This kind of non-production is the substance of nirvÄá¹‡a. How is it different from the latter ?
If one investigates in detail, one has not yet seen any difference.
Therefore, our school says that the substance of cessation due to deliberation is obtained because it universally eliminates the delusions and suffering of the three time periods.

It is said that non-analytical cessation is obtained only in the future, because conditioned factors lack conditions for arising. Due to this, the characteristics of the two cessations are not confused.
Moreover, what they say contradicts the sutras.
The sutra says:
If the five faculties are cultivated, practiced, and cultivated much, they can cause the complete cessation of suffering in the past, future, and present.
The essence of this complete cessation is nirvana. It only has the meaning of non-arising in the future, not in the past or present. Isn't this contradictory?
Although there is this text, it does not contradict the meaning.
The meaning of this sutra is to say that because the afflictions that take past and present suffering as objects are eliminated, it is called the cessation of all suffering.
As the World-Honored One said:
You should eliminate craving for form. When craving is eliminated, it is called the cessation of form and the complete understanding of form, and so on, in detail.
The elimination of past and present suffering should also be understood in the same way.

Or, this scripture has a different meaning. Past passions are those that arose in past lives, and present passions are those that arise in the present life. In order to generate future passions, these two kinds of passions give rise to seeds in the present life-stream. When these seeds are eliminated, they are also said to be eliminated, just as when retribution is exhausted, it is also said that karma is exhausted.
Future suffering and passions are said to be eliminated because they are eternally unproduced due to the absence of seeds.
If this were not so, why would it be necessary to eliminate past and present passions?
It is not necessary to expend effort to cause their cessation when they have already ceased or are in the process of cessation.
In this way, all of this is just empty talk.

First, we refute the first interpretation of the scripture, which states that when the pure path eliminates passions, there is no present or past passion that can be eliminated by that which has the capacity to take it as an object.
Yet the scripture says:
Cultivating the five faculties eliminates present and past suffering.
But at that time, are these afflictions in the future or in the present?
It cannot definitely be held that they are in the past, because they have already ceased and do not exist. How could they need to be eliminated again?
If they are in the future, they are held to be nonexistent, like flowers in the sky. How can they be objects of cognition?
If they are in the present, there would be the error of two minds occurring simultaneously. This also is not reasonable.
If you say there is a seed, the seed is not yet established.

Even if you allow that it is established, it is still not reasonable, because the substance of mind and mental factors has no object. How can it be said that they take the past and present as objects?
You should not imagine that they are pure minds, because pure minds are not afflictions.
And they are not eliminated. How can you hold that because they are eliminated, it is also said that one can eliminate the afflictions that take the past and present as objects?
Now let you speak freely. What can be eliminated in this state that takes past and present afflictions as objects?
Therefore what you say has no real meaning.
Also, if one cultivates the five faculties in order to eliminate the defilements that arise in relation to the past and future, one should be unable to eliminate them.
Why is this?
Because the sÅ«tras do not say so.

You maintain that the sÅ«tras say to eliminate past and present [defilements], and that this means to eliminate the defilements that are able to take the past and present as objects. The statement about eliminating the future should be the same.
Isn't it that the sÅ«tras say:
Cultivating the five faculties eliminates future suffering.
Because the word suffering is general, it also includes that which is able to take [suffering] as an object.
How can the defilements apart from the present be like the flowers in the sky?
Without any basis, one follows one's desires and explains [the sÅ«tra].

The World-Honored One generally says that cultivating the five faculties can eliminate the various sufferings of the past, future, and present. Why do you maintain that this statement about eliminating the past and present means eliminating the defilements that are able to take the past and present as objects?
You also maintain that this statement about eliminating the future means eliminating the essence of the future various sufferings.

You must explain the words â€œcutting off the future,â€ but if you say that one only cuts off the future passions that can take the future as an object, then the cultivation of the five faculties would be unable to cut off the passions that arise and take the future as an object.ğŸ”½If you explain the words â€œcutting off the futureâ€ as meaning that one cuts off the substance of future suffering, then this also includes the passions that take the future as an object.
Then the word â€œfutureâ€ should be general and also include the passions that take the past and present as objects.
In that case, the scriptures should not separately speak of the cutting off of past and present suffering.

For this reason, we conclude that the words â€œpast and presentâ€ in the scripture refer only to the cutting off of the substance of suffering. Therefore, we know that cessation through discrimination is the realization of the cutting off of all suffering of the three time periods, and is not merely the nonarising of future passions and suffering.

Also, the evidence that you adduce is not convincing, because it is not reasonable to say that one is said to cut off all suffering because one cuts off the passions that take past and present suffering as objects.
The statement that the cutting off of craving is the cutting off of form, etc., is also unreasonable, because the error is the same as before.
How can you say that they are cut off?
You should think about this yourself.

Also, the aggregates of form, etc., are not only called cut off because craving is cut off, because form, etc., are also objects of anger, pride, etc., and because feeling, conceptualization, karmic predispositions, and consciousness are also cut off simultaneously with craving. For this reason, you should not definitely say that form, etc., are called cut off only because the perceiving subject is cut off.
In the same way, you should explain the words â€œpast and presentâ€ in the same way, and not just say that they are cut off because the perceiving subject, i.e., the passions, is cut off.
Therefore, the evidence that you cite is in agreement with our doctrine,
but it is not in agreement with your own doctrine.
Therefore, your later interpretation of the sutra passage about seeds is completely without meaning. How can you establish the meaning of the cutting off of the seeds on the basis of that?

The analogy that you cite is not the same as the case under discussion, because action and retribution have a different substance. Apart from the passions, there is no established meaning of seeds. How can you say that the past and present multitude of sufferings are cut off because their seeds are cut off?
Therefore, your theory is meaningless and is just empty talk.
Also, to say that nonarising is the essence of nirvÄá¹‡a is the most unreasonable of all, because it would be impermanent.
The Abhidharma masters say that when the holy ones have eliminated the passions, they can retrogress and be reborn. This reasoning is sound. This will be discussed in detail later.
Therefore what they say is not acceptable to the wise.
Also, future nonexistence is admitted by their own doctrines. How can they maintain that nonexistence is nonexistent?
Because the world fully recognizes that something exists first and then becomes nonexistent.
Also, how can the nirvÄá¹‡a that the masters of the treatises hold to be only nonarising be called attained?
Because of the attainment of the antidote, one is said to attain nirvÄá¹‡a, because one realizes the future nonarising of the passions and the body that supports them.
If this is so, then the moment one first attains the holy path, one should attain the nirvÄá¹‡a that is the antidote to the passions.
Because at that moment one has already attained the body that supports the future nonarising of the passions that are the antidote to this path.
When one abides in this way and later cultivates the path of learning, one should become a post-learner, because one has already obtained the body that is incompatible with the objects of this path.
When one abides in this uninterrupted path, what has not yet been realized? One seeks the path of liberation.
Having already attained nirvÄá¹‡a, what use is there in further cultivation?
There is no such fault, because in the first moment of the holy path, the seeds of the passions are simultaneously extinguished.

As your school holds, the acquisition of the passions is not the acquisition of the future arising of the passions when the seeds of the passions have not yet been eternally extinguished, because the body that is incompatible with them is definitely opposed to them.

Also, the seeds of the passions are not eternally extinguished when the uninterrupted path has not yet arisen, and therefore there is no error in the post-learner abiding in the path of learning and not being a post-learner.
If this is so, then the post-learner should have passions.
Why is this?
Because in the first moment of the holy path, the seeds of the passions are not opposed, and they should not be opposed in the subsequent moments, because there is no difference.
However, attainment is not a simile, because it is admitted that its substance is separate, and because the holy path that arises later is different.
We admit that attainment has a separate real substance, and it does not contradict acquiescence, but it does contradict knowledge.
Why is this?
Knowledge contradicts the passions and their attainment, because attainment arises simultaneously with them.

Your school only says that the transformation of the series that is the support of the passions is the seeds of the passions, and it says that the absolute nonarising of the passions is called nirvÄá¹‡a. What is the substance of this ?
What dharma does it not contradict?
With what is it in contradiction?
Moreover, when the first holy path is about to arise, the body of the ordinary person is about to perish.

When the first holy path arises, it abandons the body of the ordinary person. Apart from that, what other seeds of the passions are there that are said not to be in contradiction with the first holy path, and that are later in contradiction with the undifferentiated path?
Therefore the meaning of your school is not well established.
Moreover, if nirvÄá¹‡a has absolutely no substance, how can the scriptures say:
Among all conditioned and unconditioned dharmas, this is the foremost.
How can something without substance be established as a dharma?
How can it be said that non-existence is supreme among non-existences?

We see that among dharmas with their own characteristics, they are said to have superiority and inferiority in relation to each other. We have never seen it said that rabbit horns and empty flowers are established as superior or inferior in relation to each other. Therefore, there is definitely a separate nirvÄá¹‡a that upholds its own characteristics, and thus it is called a dharma.
This is superior in substance to other dharmas, and thus the substance of nirvÄá¹‡a is established as truly existent.
Moreover, the World-Honored Buddha definitely says it exists, as a sÅ«tra says:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that there definitely is non-arising.
If this did not exist, the suffering of birth and death would have no end.
Because of non-arising... and so on at length.
I also do not say that nirvÄá¹‡a is completely non-existent, but it should exist as I say it does.

It is like the statement that this sound, prior to its existence, did not exist, and after its cessation, it will not exist. It cannot be said that it does not exist, and yet it is said to exist. Thus the meaning of existence is established.
It should be understood that the same is true of the explanation of unconditioned dharmas. Although they do not exist, they can still be praised.
Therefore, the ultimate non-existence of all calamities and misfortunes is called nirvÄá¹‡a. This is the most supreme among all existences and non-existences.
In order to cause those to be trained to deeply give rise to joy, it should be praised as the foremost. This explanation of nirvÄá¹‡a as existence does not establish the meaning of existence.
Why is this?
Because the two kinds of existence, real and provisional, are not compatible, and because no other kind of existence has ever been mentioned.

Although it is said that this sound, prior to its existence, did not exist, and after its cessation, it will not exist, it should be carefully and decisively determined whether this word exists refers to an ultimately non-existent thing, or whether this word exists negates other [aspects of existence] and establishes [a particular aspect of existence].
If there were a separate entity existing prior to sound, one could deny sound and say it does not exist, meaning that sound does not exist in that entity.
All mutual non-existences are definitely spoken of in dependence on existence. If one speaks of existence in regard to an ultimately non-existent entity, why not contradict reason?

The entity you have, which is called nirvÄá¹‡a, cannot be said to be non-existent because of denying the existence of suffering in it. Therefore, the example you give is incapable of proving anything.
Moreover, one should not cite conventional discourse to deny ultimate truth and support one's own position.
The author of the treatise also does not rejoice in such a meaning, because he says that non-existence cannot be established as an existent meaning.

He does not even rejoice in the words conventionally existent, so how could he speak of conditioned dharmas as existent? Therefore, the words existent definitely cannot be spoken in dependence on the ultimately non-existent.

However, they are ultimately not existent. Nirvana is neither false nor real. There is no other existence that is accepted as existent. What could be more profoundly hidden than the MÄ«mÄá¹ƒsakas' establishment of the nature of existence?
Moreover, we have never seen anywhere that non-existence has superiority or inferiority, nor that the wise praise or disparage non-existence. However, it is said:
Although existence is not existent, it can be praised.
This is just words.
How can it be said that therefore all calamities and misfortunes that are ultimately non-existent are called nirvana, and existence among existence and non-existence is the most superior?

It is said that only calamities and misfortunes with an existent substance are seen to have superiority and inferiority, not in the absence of substance. Therefore, what they say is only based on false attachment.
Isn't it that because existent dharmas have distinctions, non-existence follows them and also has distinctions, just like form, sound, etc.?
Non-existence is not different. This is also not so, because non-existence and existence are not established as being the same or different.
Does this mean that non-existence is the same as existence, or that it is different from existence?
If it is the same, it should be existence;
if it is different, it should be pointed out. What is the characteristic of the non-existence of form? What is the non-form of form?
Isn't non-existence itself the characteristic?
If so, how is the characteristic of the non-existence of form different from the non-existence of sound? Why do you say that the non-existence of form and so on are different?
Just as form and sound, although both existent, have various different characteristics and appearances;
non-existence is not so, because it has no different substance.
Therefore, what you have said, that although existence is not non-existence it can be praised, and so on, is just empty words without any real meaning.
Therefore, superiority and inferiority can only be established in existence, and there is definitely no superiority and inferiority in non-existence.
Since the World-Honored One has said that the nirvÄá¹‡a free from defilements is the most distinguished among all dharmas, it should be established as truly existent like form and so on.
If nirvana were not an existent, how could it cause those to be taught to detest birth and delight in nirvana?
Because there is no superior or inferior in a non-existent.
Also, the great sage would deceive those to be taught, because he would say that there is nirvana in a non-existent.
Also, if one generates a view that denies nirvana, it should be right view, because it is non-inverted understanding.

If you say that this view is wrong because it does not understand that nirvana is only the non-existence of the aggregates, then the view of annihilation should be right view, because it only has as its object the non-existence of the aggregates.

If you say that this view is not right because it is not a skillful means for understanding the non-existence of the aggregates, then the view that is not a skillful means for understanding the non-existence of the aggregates is not called the view of annihilation, because it is a different view.
However, all views of annihilation only have as their object the non-existence of the aggregates, so you cannot avoid the error of making them right views.
Also, if one generates views of quiescence, etc., with regard to the realm of cessation, they should not be right views, because they are not real understanding.
There is no quiescence or non-quiescence in a non-existent, just as the daughter of a stone woman is neither courageous nor timid.

We directly perceive that there is no comfort apart from illness, and no happiness apart from suffering. In the same way, there should be a state of non-existence apart from the distinctions of the conditioned.
Moreover, if nirvana has no real substance, how can it be included among the noble truths?
How can something without substance be called a truth or a falsehood?
What is the meaning of the term noble truth?
Isn't this term related to the meaning of non-error? The noble ones see existence and non-existence without error.
That is to say, the noble ones see suffering as only suffering, and see the non-existence of suffering as only non-existence.
How does this contradict the meaning of the noble truths?
This contradicts the fact that wisdom without an object cannot arise.
Yet it is said that the noble wisdom sees the non-existent object. What error is greater than this?
This meaning will be discussed in the future.
How can it be said that this is the cessation of suffering, without contradicting reason, when it is ultimately beyond words and non-existent?
It is directly seen that this name and term only arise in relation to what exists. How can this name and term arise in relation to what does not exist?
Moreover, how can non-existence become the third truth?
Here, the author of the treatise answers lightly and frivolously:
Because the noble ones see and speak of it immediately after the second [truth], it becomes the third.
This answer is unreasonable.
The intention of the questioner is this: If there is no object, cognition will definitely not arise. How can one see the unconditioned as the third truth?
Moreover, if it has no substance, but is only empty words, what meaning is there in calling it the third noble truth?

Moreover, if the cessation of suffering is only the non-existence of suffering, then one should only speak of the path that treats suffering. By speaking of the path, it is already evident that the treated suffering does not exist.
If it is not made non-existent, how can it be called the treatment?

The original basis for the path of treatment is to make suffering non-existent. Therefore, by speaking of the treatment, it is already evident that that non-existence of suffering. How can one separately speak of the cessation of suffering apart from the path of suffering?
Therefore, if nirvÄá¹‡a is apart from the path of suffering and has no separate substance, it is just empty words. What is the use of speaking of it as the third noble truth?
Moreover, you should explain: In establishing nirvÄá¹‡a as a truly existent entity, what fault do you see that you do not believe in it?
However, accepting that nirvÄá¹‡a is a truly existent separate entity does not in the least contradict the meaning and benefit of the Buddha's holy teachings.
Although they say:
If one accepts it as truly existent, it is a false imagination, and this is called a fault.
However, it is not reasonable. Imagining it as ultimately nonexistent is also called existent, because it is a false imagination.
Moreover, they have another false imagination, namely that future dharmas are nonexistent and also nonexistent, and they imagine this to be nirvÄá¹‡a. The fault is as explained above.

Moreover, they imagine that the seeds of the afflictions are neither identical with nor separate from form and other dharmas. Although they are like an axe and the person using it, they have the function of producing obstacles to the path and so forth.
Such things as these are not existent but are falsely imagined to be existent. You have long been accustomed to and hold them as your own tenets. Why do you now reject them?
Although you use the words of others to make such statements, you allow them in order to defend the tenets of the VaibhÄá¹£ikas.

Now, examining the sÅ«tra master, it seems that he is generally disgusted with and turns away from the tenets of the VaibhÄá¹£ikas, wishing to rely on empty flowers to deny that all dharmas are without self-nature.
But now, here he denies nirvÄá¹‡a, intending it as a common example to prove that the rest do not exist.

If he really wishes to defend the tenets of the VaibhÄá¹£ikas, what he says should not be partisan to the doctrine of the destruction of dharmas. Do not let the evil views of that doctrine be the dust and dirt that defile your mind. You should use the water of the true Dharma of this school to bathe yourself.ğŸ”½He also says that nirvÄá¹‡a is not something that can be attained as an essence, just as form, feeling, etc. are not something that can be attained as a function, just as the eyes, ears, etc. are not something that can be attained as an essence.

This is indeed as it should be. NirvÄá¹‡a is indeed not something that can be attained as an essence or function like form, feeling, etc. or the eyes, ears, etc. However, there is something different from those essences and functions that can be known.
Form and so on, which are conditioned, rely on their own continuity, and their substance and function are gross and obvious, easy to understand.

However, nirvana does not rely on continuity, and its substance and function are subtle and hidden, difficult to understand. Only those who possess diligent and superior contemplators, when the wisdom cultivated in meditation is present, can realize the true substance and function of nirvana.
Having emerged from contemplation, they exclaim:
How marvelous! Nirvana is the still extinction of the wonderful and detached!

It is not that the blind do not understand blue and yellow, but that even those with clear eyes do not see form. Or, even if you allow that nirvana can be called existent, you must definitely allow that its substance is not really nonexistent, because apart from real entities, existence is not established.
Moreover, characteristics are identical to substance. Since nirvana has characteristics such as extinction, stillness, and so on, the meaning of having substance is established.
Moreover, what they say:
If extinction exists separately, how can one establish the sixth case sound of the extinction of that thing?

because cessation and the conditioned factor are not mutually dependent, and they are not cause and effect in relation to each other. Only the sixth is possible, because the nonexistence of that conditioned factor is called cessation.

That explanation is unreasonable, because mutual dependence is not only present in cause and effect, and also because it is not only due to the fact that it has no separate substance. How is the cessation of that conditioned factor established?
It should be understood that the two cessations belong to the two minds, because the two minds are able to block the acquisition of that conditioned factor.
Moreover, the acquisition of cessation due to discrimination is only due to the two paths:

the first, the path of noninterruption, and the affliction to be eliminated simultaneously cease, and the second, the path of liberation, and the acquisition of cessation due to discrimination arise simultaneously.

When the acquisition of the affliction has not yet ceased, the acquisition of separation does not reach the state of having already arisen. In this way, the cessation of this and that acquisition of affliction is the arising of the acquisition of cessation due to discrimination. Therefore it is said that this and that cessation belongs to this and that conditioned factor.
This meaning has already been revealed in the scriptures. The scriptures say:
Venerable One!
As for the cessation of cessation, by what cessation is it said to cease?
It is said to cease due to the cessation of the five appropriated aggregates.
If there were no separate cessation, the sÅ«tra would only have to say:
Whose cessation is it?
It is the cessation of the five appropriated aggregates.
What does it mean to say it is said to cease due to the cessation of the five appropriated aggregates?

One should know that when the acquisition of afflictions ceases, it is called the cessation of afflictions. I never allow that the cessation of mere suffering is called nirvÄá¹‡a. Because it is accepted that suffering ceases, apart from the path of abandoning suffering, one separately attains the cessation of discrimination and only then is it called nirvÄá¹‡a.

If cessation were not separate, there would be the previously mentioned error, namely, that an arhat would have afflictions, or that when abiding in the path of learning, the afflictions would already be absent, because there would be no difference later on.
Here the master of the sÅ«tra again says:
Why is this cessation definitely attributed to this attainment?
Isn't this just evasive sophistry to avoid the difficulty?
Even if there is no definite cause for the disjunction from the same category of the single characteristic, what fault is there in this?
By the power of a single path, all bonds are extinguished and one totally obtains separation from bonds. What need is there for a fixed cause?

Or else, the path that is able to eliminate is the fixed cause for this. Because the attainment of separation is brought about by the path, the extinction of bonds eliminated by other paths of elimination is not obtained by other paths.

Therefore you should rejoice. The cessation obtained by a single path of elimination is not a single substance. What fixed cause is there to say that this belongs to craving and that belongs to anger, etc.?
Even if there is no fixed relation, what fault is there?
That is to say, in a single category, all that is eliminated is eliminated by a single path. The separation obtained is the same attainment. What need is there for a fixed cause?
Or else, as explained above.
What was explained above?

That is to say, by the nature of things, being related is without confusion. From the very beginning, craving, etc., and cessation are related by the nature of things, definitely without confusion. When the path of elimination arises, it is able to totally realize and obtain. Therefore, even without a fixed cause, there is no fault.
If you do not agree, then you contradict holy teachings, because there is a holy teaching that shows that nirvana has only nonexistence as its nature.
A scripture says,

All suffering is completely eliminated, each and every thing is abandoned, exhausted, extinguished, calmed, and completely destroyed, and the remaining suffering does not continue, is not grasped, and does not arise. This is ultimate quiescence, this is ultimate excellence, that is, the abandonment of all supports and the exhaustion, extinction, detachment, and cessation of all craving is called nirvana.ğŸ”½Also, if you admit that the substance of nirvana is only nonexistence, then you give a good interpretation of the scriptures that use metaphors,

The Abhidharma masters have already explained this, saying that the meaning of the extinction of suffering has two aspects:

The Buddha observes that the inclinations of those to be converted are not the same, and therefore he expounds these two kinds of meanings of cessation.
That is to say, in some places he says that there is no separate substance, as in the two scriptures quoted above.
Or else, in some places he says that there is a separate substance, as a scripture says:
There definitely is non-arising.
And a scripture says:
There is a place where there is separation.
And there is another scripture that says:
I observe that in reality there is the meaning of the unconditioned, namely nirvÄá¹‡a.
And there is another scripture that says:
Because the five appropriated aggregates cease, it is said to be cessation.
This kind is truly abundant, and therefore my school does not contradict the holy teachings.

Moreover, the extinction of the flame of a lamp as explained in the scriptures is because apart from the lamp there is a characteristic of impermanence. What contradiction is there in the meaning of this analogy?

Its substance is not nonexistent, and there is no error in speaking of it in this way.

Other masters say:

On this point, the author of the commentary says:
We see that this seventh conversion of sound has no power to prove that nirvÄá¹‡a exists. Why do you say that it is based on the nonarising of this nirvÄá¹‡a?

if this does not exist, why seek them?

How was it refuted above?

Also, if suffering does not arise due to the path or attainment, then at the time of the first moment of the path, afflictions and suffering would already be absent, as explained above.
Then, abiding in the path of learning, afflictions should be absent.
If it is said that because the seeds of afflictions have not yet been extinguished, when the path of elimination arises, why are the seeds not extinguished?
because it is directly opposed to it, like light and darkness.

In this way, the master of the sÅ«tra has already refuted the cause and established that the essence of nirvÄá¹‡a truly exists.
Other masters say:

Their words are unreasonable, because we have already established that the nonobstruction of space is really existent, and it is not included in the category of cause and effect. This is also the case with nirvana.

Another says:

Those who say that nirvana has no substance will never say that the name itself is nonexistence;
Those who say that nirvana has substance will never say that the name itself is nirvana. Therefore, what they say also contradicts correct reasoning.

As the World-Honored One said:

Moreover, the sÅ«tra only says:

However, it is universally recognized in the world that what is manifested through dependence on something else is a real thing, just as light is manifested through dependence on darkness, etc.

The conditioned realm, the unconditioned realm, and the realm of cessation, there is arising and non-arising, and the noble truth of the cessation of suffering, which I now fully understand to be a state of peace.
Such statements are also not contradictory, because they are established based on the aggregates.

This is also a rash statement. Even if the three realms, etc. are established based on the aggregates, since there is no evidence, how can it be definitely known that their substance does not really exist?

Moreover, it is said that because they are manifested by each other, they are real entities, which is completely established. Without substance, it is not possible to be manifested by others, just as light, etc. manifest darkness, etc.
Moreover, what they say:
The sutraâ€™s statement that there is an element of cessation is not contradictory, because it is manifested in dependence on the existence of the body.
The statement that there is no arising is not contradictory, because it is established as non-arising in reality, and it is precisely this non-arising that is called arising.

The meaning of the cessation of continuity is also unreasonable, as stated above, because it is manifested in dependence on another and is real. Arising and non-arising have different natures, and what is real should not be said to be unreal.
Apart from the real and the unreal, there is no other existence.

How can it be definitely said that only the non-continuation of arising is called the cessation of continuity, and not a separate existent?
If a separate existent is admitted, the statement that there is no arising can be established as having the meaning of existence;
if there is no separate existent, it should not be called existent, as explained above.

The BhagavÄn should have only said in the sÅ«tra that there is arising but no turning, and should not have said that there is no arising. The BhagavÄn should not have spoken in error about ultimate truth, because both existence and nonexistence are said to exist, and that is a mistaken statement.
Is it because arising is said to exist as if it were non-arising that its substance is not real?
Or is it because non-arising is said to exist as if it were arising that its substance is real?
It is in order to cause such a mistaken mind to arise.

Moreover, the path of severing continuity has not yet arisen, and after the path has arisen it exists, and after the path has regressed it does not exist again, because the holy ones regress and give rise to delusions. Then the severed continuity should not be unconditioned.

If you say that nirvana is real and permanent, the World-Honored One should make a distinction here.

Now one should contemplate and discern the substance of non-analytical cessation. The characteristics explained by the master of this sÅ«tra are said:

Because their faculties are superior, the passions are not produced. What need is there to suppose that cessation not due to deliberation is a real entity?
In what sense do we speak of superior faculties?
If this refers only to the knowledge of nonproduction, then it means that because they have the superior faculties of the knowledge of nonproduction, the passions are not produced.
We must consider this further.
All arhats have eliminated the passions. Why is there a difference in whether or not they have this superior knowledge?

If it is said that the faculty of final nirvana is superior to the faculty of retrogressing, this is also unreasonable, because one who has obtained this faculty may still retrogress and generate the passions.

That is, one of the nature of retrogressing may transform and obtain a superior faculty, up to the ability to penetrate, but still encounters conditions that cause him to retrogress and abide in the stage of learning, and generate various passions.

If, having obtained a superior faculty, the passions do not arise, then one who transforms from the nature of retrogressing and obtains the faculty of reflection would not again generate all the passions.

However, this is not the case. Consequently, we know that there are arhats who, because of the absence of conditions for the generation of the passions, obtain cessation resulting from discrimination. By the power of this, they are able to block the passions and cause them never to arise again.
If there is the meaning of retrogressing from the knowledge of nonproduction, all is reasonable.
However, retrogressing is not established, and therefore all is not so.
The meaning of retrogressing must exist, and we will consider it later.
